comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Thanks Wystan for the links to the articles, and for determining the date, which will add some certainty to the image.  We'll add that to the record the next time we update it. I'm still not sure what we are looking at in this image: a freight car built to hold and transport the stone?

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: No, that appears to be a gigantic stoneboat, perched on rollers,  with a massive framework surrounding the stone, probably to prevent accidental breakage or chipping while in transit. The stories suggest that it was Rockefeller's plan to move the stone in one piece, and to have it carved into an  ornamental fountain on the site. The words "George Brown & Co., N. Y.," have been painted on the sides of the wooden cribbing that surrounds and protects the stone.

comment.author: 10212892@N07
comment._content: The stone was both quarried and carved in Stonington, Maine, before being shipped down to Tarrytown. The "vertical striations" are actually the wooden support structure surrounding the stone and you can't see the stone at all in this picture. Once the stone made it up the hill to the estate it became the upper basin of the Oceanus Fountain in the forecourt. (see this photo: www.flickr.com/photos/tomchatt/4170893041/) You can see an indication of the shape of the stone underneath the wooden protection in this photo - the narrower rim on the left side and angle below. Hope this sheds some more light on the photo.
